bibl.title: Letter from Wickliffe Rose to Henry Rose Carter, December 29, 1922

div1.p: Rose sends Carter a letter from Dr. White speculating on the Cose yellow fever case.

div1.head: Letter from Wickliffe Rose to Henry Rose Carter, December 29, 1922
div1.opener:
ADMINISTRATIVE STAFF
----
WICKLIFFE ROSE
GENERAL DIRECTOR
JOHN A. FERRELL, M.D.
DIRECTOR FOR
THE UNITED STATES
VICTOR G. HEISER, M.D.
DIRECTOR FOR
THE EAST
H. H. HOWARD, M.D.
DIRECTOR FOR
THE WEST INDIES
F. F. RUSSELL, M.D.
DIRECTOR OF
PUBLIC HEALTH LABORATORIES
Tampico
I. H. C.
I.H B.
Tampico
MEMBERS
----
GEORGE E. VINCENT
CHAIRMAN
HERMANN M. RIGGS
WALLACE BUTTRICK
SIMON FLEXNER
RAYMOND B. FOSDICK
FREDERICK T. GATES
EDWIN O. JORDAN
VERNON KELLOGG
T. MITCHELL PRUDDEN
JOHN D. ROCKEFELLER, JR.
WICKLIFFE ROSE
VICTOR C. VAUGHAN
WILLIAM H. WELCH
EDWIN R. EMBREE
SECRETARY
FLORENCE M. READ
ASSISTANT SECRETARY
THE ROCKEFELLER FOUNDATION
INTERNATIONAL HEALTH BOARD
61 BROADWAY, NEW YORK
December 29, 1922
Dear Doctor Carter:
div1.p:
You will find enclosed copy of a letter from Doctor White
in which he expresses his tentative views with reference to the
John Cose case of yellow fever on the “H. H. Rogers.” With refer-
ence to this case, we understand that Doctor Scannell was willing
to concur in the diagnosis of yellow fever because the man showed
some symptoms of yellow fever and the case appeared to be doubtful.
Doctor Scannell did not see Mr. Cose until the tenth day of his
illness.

In another letter Doctor White wrote as follows:
“I feel much relieved about Guiana, but am
still by no means entirely reassured as
to the north coast and the Windward
Islands - and, don't forget that if the
Burnham “smuggled” Y.F. into Mobile,
another shifty schooner captain might do
the same into Guiana from Ceara, and much
easier.”
div1.closer:
Very sincerely yours, Wickliffe Rose. Doctor H. R. Carter
Assistant Surgeon General, USPHS
2121 California Street N.W.
Washington, D.C.
WRR:EP E
